RBB

Method Detail

create

public static RBB create(java.lang.String url,
                         java.lang.String name)
                  throws java.sql.SQLException
create a new RBB instance connected to the specified JDBC url. The URL specifies where the database will be stored on disk (or in memory) The name is a human-readable name used by some applications including RBB ML and will be defaulted to the data/time if null. Raises an exception if there was already an RBB or bare H2 database at the URL

Throws:
java.sql.SQLException

connect

public static RBB connect(java.lang.String url)
                   throws java.sql.SQLException
Connect to an RBB previously created with create()

Throws:
java.sql.SQLException

createOrConnect

public static RBB createOrConnect(java.lang.String url)
                           throws java.sql.SQLException
If there was no database with this url, create it. If there was already a database initialized as an RBB at this url, return an rbb instance. Otherwise raises an exception, for example if the database exists but is not (yet) an rbb

Throws:
java.sql.SQLException

fromOpenRBB

public static RBB fromOpenRBB(java.sql.Connection conn)
make an RBB instance to reference an existing H2 Connection to an RBB DB.

This used for RBB Event Listeners, because H2 fires the trigger with a DB handle that's good only in that context.

db

public java.sql.Connection db()

disconnect

public void disconnect()
                throws java.sql.SQLException
Close the underlying db connection. This is the only place in the RBB codebase this occurs. In applications that close an RBB but keep running it is important to call this; otherwise the connection may stay open and the DB files remain even if no RBB instances exist.

Throws:
java.sql.SQLException

addEventListener

public void addEventListener(RBBEventListener listener,
                             RBBFilter f)
                      throws java.sql.SQLException
 Each listener will be notified through its own thread,
 through an H2EventTCPClient (even if the server is in the same process).
 This makes the semantics consistent whether the server is embedded or remote.
 (If this isn't what you want, see addLocalEventListener.)
 This means that listeners must NOT make un-coordinated access to this
 RBB instance (or others sharing the same h2 Connection via fromOpenRBB).
 For example if the listener executes a query during a notification it must
 do so inside a synchronization block:

 synchronized(rbb.db()) {
   ...
 }

 Moreover if the main thread calls addEventListener, it must also synchronize
 on the db Connection if there are Listeners that may be accessing the Connection.

Throws:
java.sql.SQLException

removeEventListener

public void removeEventListener(RBBEventListener listener)
                         throws java.sql.SQLException
Throws:
java.sql.SQLException

setName

public void setName(java.lang.String name)
             throws java.sql.SQLException
Set a persistent name for the RBB. Doesn't necessarily have anything to do with the pathname or filename of the database.

Throws:
java.sql.SQLException

                         throws java.sql.SQLException

addLocalEventListener

public void addLocalEventListener(RBBEventListener listener,
                                  RBBFilter filter)
                           throws java.sql.SQLException
listeners added this way will be notified synchronously, in the thread running the database engine. If you call this from a client in a different process from the database server, it will not be called at all. H2 does not allow modifying the database within this context. Must be removed with removeLocalEventListener.

Throws:
java.sql.SQLException

removeLocalEventListener

public void removeLocalEventListener(RBBEventListener listener)
                              throws java.sql.SQLException
Throws:
java.sql.SQLException
